title: typography and the city
content:
hello,

as a part of my architectural studies at the university of darmstadt in germany, i'm currently working on an analysis of the relationship of typography and space and character of a city and the impact they have on each other.  
my main emphasis so far is:  
:: how much a city's type (ci) represents its charcter, and/or space  
:: can one type represent the many different charcters and atmospheres most modern citys include in their metropolitain area?  
:: how much does a type named after a city represent the city, what is the inspiration for the name?  
:: are there other ways of creating a city's typography?  
:: does a city have a certain typographical style? in the signs? in the graffiti?  
...  
i'd be happy about any comment, link and every other bit of information, that would help me gather information on this subject!

björn asmussen
author: björn asmussen

comments.content:
There was a lot of talk about this at TypeCon05. Some of the talks may become available. Paula Scher's presentation was spot on your subject.  
Also look at the typeface Gotham as it relates to New York.

ChrisL
Gerard Unger [tells a great story](http://web.archive.org/web/20111231003207/http:/www.gerardunger.com/graphicdesign/graphicdesign6.html) about designing Capitolium for Rome.
Jean Francois [tells a great story](http://web.archive.org/web/20111231003207/http:/www.typofonderie.com/gazette/articles/parisine) about designing Parisine for the Paris metro.

Dear Björn,

Take a look at Simon Loxley's _Type: The Secret History of Letters_ (London, 2004), chap. 9, on the London Underground. That's fourteen pages on one aspect of the typography of one city, so producing a study about the typography of all cities in the world would probably be either overly large or overly generalized. You might want to narrow your project. Good luck!

There's also some really good commentary on the recent  
Prague city ID in one of the earlier issues of TYPO:  
 [http://www.magtypo.cz/english.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20111231003207/http:/www.magtypo.cz/english.html "http://www.magtypo.cz/english.html")

hhp
The [Twin](http://web.archive.org/web/20111231003207/http:/design.umn.edu/go/project/TCDC03.1.TTC) typeface was intended to be site-specific.

thanx for the hint on the book!  
the aim of the project so far (i'm just at the start of my research!)is not to analyse each and every city and its typographic applications. my aim is to generate an overview of possible ways of dealing with citys to generate a certain typography. based on this information i want to focus on the relation of space and typography (an the other way around, as in buildings and citys based on letters f.e. the alphabet city by paul noble).  
or in other words: what does it need to transform space into typography and typography into (usable/interesting)space.

\> _what does it need to transform space into typography and typography into (usable/interesting)space._

I generally think of typography in 2-dimensions and architecture in 3-dimentions. But I did study architectonics under [**John Hejduk**](http://web.archive.org/web/20111231003207/http:/www.architectureweek.com/2003/0108/design_1-1.html) who was more a poet visionary than a brick-and-mortar architect.

Also, I've always felt that Antoni Gaudí's [Casa Batlló](http://web.archive.org/web/20111231003207/http:/www.greatbuildings.com/buildings/Casa_Batllo.html) in Barcelona was as textured as Catalan manuscripts, if that's what you mean.

Norbert, lazy with the diacritics again - tsk tsk.  
But great taste in architecture.

hhp

Thanks, Hrant... fixed!

And this small gallery of [John Hejduk's work](http://web.archive.org/web/20111231003207/http:/www.kmtspace.com/kmt/hejduk.htm) can be viewed as typography and sculpture. (especially the 'shaping 3D space' and '1/2 house')

ChrisL

hey norbert,  
i think architecture and typographie have very much in common. they both deal with interior space, the shape and its expression -letter/house-, as well as the relation of the shapes to each other. -kerning/city-  
besides, both try to communicate at least one additional dimension and they are generally published in 2D.

The best parallel I've found to type design is shoemaking.

hhp

Hrant, I've heard of clothing fashions as parallel, but not shoemaking per se.  
The more I think of it, the more it seems to fit. :-)

It's really a superb parallel, especially in terms of text fonts: shoes that are slightly uncomfortable seem fine when walking around the house, but if you try a mile in them, you pay - and you can't judge by looking at them either.

hhp

Not to trumpet your cause Hrant but, I guess only display fonts require shoe horns :-)

ChrisL

It probably deserves a new topic of Type Parallels to run it through the gauntlet.

If you compare reading with modes of walking (inclusive of running, dancing, hiking and so on) and shoes or foot apparel as type, you can go pretty far with the analogy.
But my question is when does Nike get involved (Just do it®)

They hired Carson didn't they? (As if...)

hhp

It's an excellent parallel. Comfort for long or short distances, proper selection, purpose, durability, versatility, style.

And they have arches like letters! And plus they have those little feet on them!!! ; )

you can check out a brilliant overview on the devellopment of Milano City typeface from the Linotype custom type services department:

[http://www.linotype.com/2088-24-2088/pdf/00\_home/images/home\_07/MILANO\_C...](http://web.archive.org/web/20111231003207/http:/www.linotype.com/2088-24-2088/pdf/00_home/images/home_07/MILANO_CITY.pdf "http://www.linotype.com/2088-24-2088/pdf/00\_home/images/home\_07/MILANO\_CITY.pdf")

it outlines features and perceived traits of the city as they had to be found in the overall personality of the typeface, while keeping up with the modern and upscale look Milano sought to project.
